In the same period, when she worked again with ''Guess?'' (creating, with the model [[Stefano Sala]], an advertising spot in [[Cefalù]] in [[Sicily]])[https://siviaggia.it/notizie/belen-a-cefalu-in-sicilia-per-uno-spot-servizio-fotografico-in-spiaggia/167318/] and with ''[[Jadea]]'',[http://www.jadea.it/] Belen was model and testimonial of new wavy hair plate of ''[[Bellissima Imetec]]''.[https://bellissima.com/it/] === Showgirl === Belén has worked in Italy since 2004 as a [[fashion model]] and a variety show host. Her debut as a showgirl and television host dates back to November 2006, with the programs of [[Tele Boario 1]], the local television network of [[Val Camonica]].{{cite web|url=http://www.oggi.it/attualita/personaggi/2010/07/27/belen-rodriguez-ecco-il-suo-debutto-in-tv/|title=Belen Rodriguez, guarda il suo debutto in Tv|publisher=}} After having signed with [[Paola Benegas]] as her first agent in Italy, in the spring of 2007 Belén debuted on Italian national television, hosting, with the singer [[Taiyo Yamanouchi]], the late-night comedy show ''[[La tintoria]]''{{cite web|url=http://archiviostorico.corriere.it/2007/gennaio/03/Satira_lavanderia_con_Dott_Asl_co_9_070103045.shtml|title=Archivio Corriere della Sera|publisher=}} on [[Rai 3]] (during this show Yamanouchi urged Belen to start a career as a singer, an idea she rejected, saying she preferred to stay in the television industry). In the summer of 2007 Belén hosted, with [[Fabrizio Frizzi]], the prime time variety show ''[[Circo Massimo Show]]''.{{cite web|url=http://archiviostorico.corriere.it/2007/giugno/20/FILM_PROGRAMMI_OGGI_co_9_070620058.shtml|title=Archivio Corriere della Sera|publisher=}} In the autumn of 2007, Belén with [[Lucia Ocone]], co-hosted the late-night variety show ''[[Stile libero Max]]'' hosted by [[Max Giusti]] on [[Rai 2]]; at the end of 2007 Belén appeared in several episodes as a participant and as a journalist for [[Videonews]] in ''[[Verissimo (TV series)|Verissimo]]'', the infotainment program hosted by [[Silvia Toffanin]] on Saturday afternoon on [[Canale 5]]. Belén appeared as a showgirl in the episode of 4 April 2008 (during which she introduced her sister Cecilia, who was 18 years old at that time, in her Italian television debut) of the prime time variety show ''[[I raccomandati]]'', hosted by [[Carlo Conti]] and [[Alessia Ventura]] on [[Rai 1]]. In the spring of 2008 Belén appeared as a journalist and co-host (with [[Selvaggia Lucarelli]] and others), in ''Pirati'', a late-night show of [[Rai 2]].{{cite web|url=http://archiviostorico.corriere.it/2008/maggio/08/Film_programmi_co_9_080508055.shtml|title=Archivio Corriere della Sera|publisher=}} In the summer of 2008 Belén appeared as a showgirl and a journalist for [[Videonews]] (with [[Aída Yéspica]], [[Ainett Stephens]], [[Melita Toniolo]] and others) in the [[Italia 1]] television program ''[[Lucignolo]]''. In the autumn of 2008 Belén, after modeling for the ''[[Max (German magazine)|Max]]'' magazine a few months previously, appeared in the 8th season of ''[[L'isola dei famosi]]'', a [[reality show]] aired by [[Rai 2]] and hosted by [[Simona Ventura]]. Belén won 2nd place, arousing considerable interest in the Italian television audience; according to Italian television critics, this event was the "turning point" in Belen's career, marking the beginning of her becoming "a big celebrity".{{cite web|url=http://www.davidemaggio.it/archives/78895/fenomenologia-di-belen-rodriguez-la-corona-del-successo|title=FENOMENOLOGIA DI BELEN RODRIGUEZ: LA CORONA DEL SUCCESSO|publisher=}} In December 2008 Belén joined the cast of the agency's artists ''[[Arcobaleno Tre]]'' of [[Lucio Presta]]; this news was covered widely in the Italian press because Lucio Presta was the agent of [[Paolo Bonolis]] and [[Roberto Benigni]]. In the winter of 2009 Belén hosted, with [[Claudio Amendola]] and [[Teo Mammucari]], the eleventh season of the prime time variety show ''[[Scherzi a parte]]'' on [[Canale 5]]. From 2009 to 2011 Belén appeared in [[television commercial]]s advertising the [[mobile phone]] network [[Telephone company|operating companies]]; during this period Belén began [[Endorsement (advertising)|endorsing]] and modeling [[Luxury goods|luxury]] [[jewellery]]. In the summer of 2009{{cite web|url=http://archiviostorico.corriere.it/2009/giugno/11/funzione_dei_Papi_dei_Mammucari_co_9_090611086.shtml|title=Archivio Corriere della Sera|publisher=}} she was the co-host of [[Teo Mammucari]] on the [[Canale 5]] quiz show ''[[Sarabanda]]'', for which she had recorded the theme song. In the autumn of 2009 [[Mediaset]] offered her a contract for the 2010 year to co-host, with Mammucari, the new prime time variety show ''[[Fenomenal]]'' on [[Italia 1]], which she rejected on the advice of her agent, [[Lucio Presta]]; at the end of 2009, Belén was a [[guest star]] on 23 November episode in the 10th season of the ''[[Grande Fratello|Italian Big Brother]]'', a [[Canale 5]] reality show hosted by [[Alessia Marcuzzi]];{{cite web|url=http://www.davidemaggio.it/archives/15673/grande-fratello-10-belen-rodriguez-due-nuovi-concorrenti-quinta-puntata|title=GRANDE FRATELLO 10: BELEN RODRIGUEZ E DUE NUOVI CONCORRENTI FANNO IL LORO INGRESSO NELLA CASA.|publisher=}} at around this time the Italian press launched a rumour saying that Mammucari and Rodríguez were going to be asked by [[Mediaset]] to join the cast of presenters of the 2009–2010 edition of ''[[Striscia la Notizia]]'', but [[Antonio Ricci (producer)|Antonio Ricci]] (the producer of ''Striscia'') denied this{{cite web|url=http://www.davidemaggio.it/archives/5895/belen-largentina-che-vorremmo-vedere-in-coppia-con-la-svizzera|title=BELEN, L'ARGENTINA CHE VORREMMO VEDERE IN COPPIA CON LA SVIZZERA|publisher=}} (Belén joined ''Striscia'' as host in 2015). In the winter of 2010 Belén appeared with her sister Cecilia in the late-night variety show ''[[Chiambretti Night]]'' on [[Italia 1]].{{cite web|url=http://www.davidemaggio.it/archives/27443/cecilia-e-belen-rodriguez-ospiti-al-chiambretti-night-dedicato-alle-sorelle-ditalia-si-desteranno-gli-italiani|title=CECILIA E BELEN RODRIGUEZ OSPITI AL CHIAMBRETTI NIGHT DEDICATO ALLE|publisher=}} At around this time Belén rejected the offer of [[Italia 1]] to appear with [[Teo Mammucari]] in the proposed{{cite web|url=http://www.davidemaggio.it/archives/6311/love-bugs-o-tempora-o-tanga-belen-pigliatutto-sara-protagonista-della-quarta-stagione-in-coppia-con-mammucari|title=LOVE BUGS: O TEMPORA O TANGA, BELEN PIGLIATUTTO SARA' PROTAGONISTA DELLA QUARTA STAGIONE IN COPPIA CON MAMMUCARI|publisher=}} 4th season (never realized) of the sitcom ''[[Love Bugs]]'', preferring, on the advice of her agent [[Lucio Presta]], to host, with Cecilia as ''1st dancer'', ''[[Stiamo tutti bene]]'' (late-night of [[Rai 2]]).[http://www.davidemaggio.it/archives/27769/belen-torna-in-rai-con-%E2%80%9Cstiamo-tutti-bene%E2%80%9D] Belén was a guest performer on the most prestigious televised Italian song contest, the ''[[Sanremo Music Festival]]'', where she sang a duet with the Italian singer [[Toto Cutugno]] on 18 February 2010, to acclaim from the public and critics. At around this time, the Italian press announced Belén's upcoming participation{{cite web|url=http://www.davidemaggio.it/archives/26934/belen-dice-si-a-tinto-brass-per-il-sequel-di-cosi-fan-tutte|title=BELEN DICE SI A TINTO BRASS PER IL SEQUEL DI COSI' FAN TUTTE.|publisher=}} in a movie directed by [[Tinto Brass]], but this news turned out to be an [[April Fool's joke]] that caused various controversies in the Italian news media. In February 2011 Belén co-hosted the [[Sanremo Music Festival 2011]] with [[Gianni Morandi]] and [[Elisabetta Canalis]].{{cite web|url=http://www.corriere.it/spettacoli/10_ottobre_05/morandi-stop-trattativa-sanremo-rai_c3a0c644-d098-11df-9b01-00144f02aabc.shtml |title=Festival di Sanremo, ok a Morandi Ci saranno anche Belen e Elisabetta – Corriere della Sera |website=Corriere.it |date=24 December 2009 |accessdate=21 July 2016}} In the spring of 2011 Belen hosted, with [[Francesco Facchinetti]], ''[[Ciak... si canta!]]'' aired by [[Rai 1]].[https://www.davidemaggio.it/archives/37710/ciak-si-canta-francesco-facchinetti-e-belen-rodriguez-debuttano-questa-sera-rispolverando-lapplausometro] In the summer of 2011 Belen participated[https://www.davidemaggio.it/archives/41563/la-notte-degli-chef-belen-rodriguez-al-posto-della-canalis] in the variety show ''[[La notte degli chef]]'' (aired by [[Canale 5]] and hosted by [[Alfonso Signorini]]). In the autumn of 2011[https://www.davidemaggio.it/archives/44812/colorado-belen-rodriguez-e-paolo-ruffini-al-debutto-lui-sogna-di-fare-la-spalla-lei-di-diventare-come-la-de-filippi] Belén hosted the comedy show of [[Italia 1]] ''{{ill|Colorado (TV series)|it|Colorado (programma televisivo 2003)|lt=Colorado}}'' with [[Paolo Ruffini]], [[Digei Angelo]] and [[Chiara Francini]]. In the winter of 2012 Belén hosted on [[Canale 5]] the talent show ''[[Italia's Got Talent]]'' with [[Simone Annicchiarico]]: they hosted this program again in the winter of 2013 and in the autumn of 2013. In the spring of 2012, Belén performed in the 11th season of the talent show [[Amici di Maria De Filippi]] as part of the programme's regular [[dance]] troupe. Substituting for {{ill|Ivana Mrazova|it|Ivana Mrázová}}, Belén co-presented, with [[Elisabetta Canalis]], during the first two evenings, in February 2012, of the [[Sanremo Music Festival 2012|62th Sanremo Music Festival]].[http://www.tvblog.it/post/32873/sanremo-2012-elisabetta-canalis-sostituisce-ivana-mrazova-la-rai-sminuira-la-mediasettara-belen] In the autumn of 2012[https://www.davidemaggio.it/archives/63322/colorado-stasera-si-torna-a-ridere-su-italia1-con-belen-rodriguez-e-paolo-ruffini] Belen hosted the comedy show of [[Italia 1]] ''[[Colorado (TV series)|Colorado]]'' with [[Paolo Ruffini]], [[Digei Angelo]], [[Elena Morali]] and [[Jiang Wei]]. In the summer of 2013, Belén and Stefano De Martino (who was at that time her future first husband) participated in the prime time program ''[[Studio 5]]'' aired by [[Canale 5]].[https://www.davidemaggio.it/archives/76820/belen-e-stefano-per-la-prima-volta-in-tv-insieme-a-studio-5-di-signorini] In the spring of 2014 Belén was the [[guest star]] in two programs: ''[[Colorado (TV series)|Colorado]]'' aired by [[Italia 1]] and ''[[Giass]]'' aired by [[Canale 5]].[http://gentevip.it/televisione/giass-ultima-puntata-da-luca-e-paolo-arrivano-belen-rodriguez-e-gerry-scotti/56827] In February 2014, during the ''[[Sanremo Music Festival 2010|64th Sanremo Festival]]'', Belen participated, as a speaker and radio presenter,[http://genova.repubblica.it/dettaglio-news/-/4461419] at the talk show of [[RTL 102.5]] ''Password'' to comment on the event and then she was the [[guest star]] of ''[[Domenica In|Domenica In - Speciale Sanremo]]'' aired by [[Rai 1]].[http://www.tvblog.it/post/520249/domenica-in-de-martino-si-collega-con-belen-sul-palco-di-sanremo-uno-schiaffo-alla-bellezza-flop-di-fazio] In the spring of 2014 Belen hosted the afternoon program of [[Italia 1]] ''{{ill|Come mi vorrei|it|Come mi vorrei (programma televisivo)}}'', Italian version of ''[[Plain Jane (TV series)|Plain Jane]]''.[http://realityshow.blogosfere.it/2014/03/belen-rodriguez-a-come-mi-vorrei-e-ospite-a-colorado-aggredita-piu-di-una-volta-dalla-durso.html] In May–June 2014 Belén took part as "first dancer",[http://www.vanityfair.it/show/tv/14/05/12/belen-chiambretti-supermarket] of ''{{ill|Chiambretti Supermarket|it|Chiambretti Supermarket}}'', a [[late-night talk show]] aired by [[Italia 1]] and hosted by [[Piero Chiambretti]]. In the autumn of 2014[http://www.davidemaggio.it/archives/104831/tu-si-que-vales-conducono-francesco-sole-e-belen-rodriguez] Belén hosted on [[Canale 5]] the {{ill|first season|it|Tú sí que vales (Italia, prima edizione)}} of ''{{ill|Tú sí que vales|it|Tú sí que vales}}'' with [[Francesco Sole]]. On 8 February 2015 Belen was the co-host[http://www.tvblog.it/post/733776/avanti-un-altro-belen-co-conduttrice-alla-domenica-gerry-se-vuoi-vado-in-vacanza-con-bonolis] of [[Gerry Scotti]] in the sunday special episode of the quiz show ''{{ill|Avanti un altro! Pure di domenica...|it|Avanti un altro!#Avanti un altro! Pure di domenica…}}'' aired by [[Canale 5]].[http://www.gossipetv.com/belen-rodriguez-il-trucco-del-tatuaggio-sul-braccio-151799] On 13 February 2015[http://www.gossipetv.com/belen-stefano-e-emma-incontro-evitato-sanremo-152496] Belén and Stefano De Martino (who was at that time her first husband) participated in the recordings of an episode of the Saturday evening people show ''{{ill|C'è posta per te|it|C'è posta per te (programma televisivo)}}'' hosted by [[Maria De Filippi]]; the episode was aired on 14 March.[http://www.gossipetv.com/belen-e-stefano-a-ce-posta-per-te-un-gesto-che-commuove-159262] In 2015, Belen preferred to send her sister Cecilia] to the ''[[L%27Isola_dei_Famosi#Season_10|L'isola dei famosi 10]]'' instead of Stefano De Martino, who was at that time Belén's first husband. Outside of [[Mediaset]], in 2015 Belen was the guest star in two [[prime time]] programs: on 28 May 2015 in the talk show ''{{ill|Announo|it|Announo}}'' aired by [[La7]] and hosted by [[Giulia Innocenzi]],[http://www.davidemaggio.it/archives/117163/announo-belen-rodriguez-ospite-su-la7-con-stefano-rodota] on 11 December 2015 the variety show ''[[Andrea Bocelli - Il mio cinema]]'' hosted by [[Massimo Giletti]] in honour of [[Andrea Bocelli]] and aired on [[Rai 1]];[http://www.tvblog.it/post/1221446/andrea-bocelli-il-mio-cinema-11-dicembre-2015-diretta] inside [[Mediaset]] Belen was the guest star and the co-host of ''[[Striscia la Notizia]]'' with [[Ficarra e Picone]] on 30 April 2015[http://www.gossipetv.com/belen-rodriguez-da-striscia-la-notizia-una-gradita-sorpresa-168608] and of ''{{ill|Arena di Verona, lo spettacolo sta per iniziare|it|Arena di Verona, lo spettacolo sta per iniziare}}'' with [[Elena Santarelli]] and [[Paolo Bonolis]] on 3 June 2015.[http://www.davidemaggio.it/archives/117363/arena-di-verona-2015-lo-spettacolo-sta-per-iniziare-per-la-prima-volta-su-canale-5-con-paolo-bonolis-e-belen-rodriguez] In the autumn of 2015 Belen and [[Francesco Sole]] hosted the {{ill|second season|it|Tú sí que vales (Italia, seconda edizione)}} of ''{{ill|Tú sí que vales|it|Tú sí que vales}}''.[http://www.tvblog.it/post/1162577/tu-si-que-vales-2015-anticipazioni-e-foto-anteprima-blogo] In the winter of 2016 Belen hosted[http://bubinoblog.altervista.org/pequenos-gigantes-un-nuovo-successo-di-maria-de-filippi-ecco-le-prime-impressioni-dalla-registrazione-di-oggi/] in the prime time of [[Canale 5]] the {{ill|first season|it|Pequeños_gigantes_(Italia)#Prima_edizione}} of the talent show for children[http://bubinoblog.altervista.org/piccoli-giganti-la-prima-prova-col-pubblico-dal-nostro-inviato-master/] ''{{ill|Pequeños gigantes|it|Pequeños_gigantes_(Italia)}}''. In September 2016 Belen hosted ''[[Striscia la notizia]]'' with [[Michelle Hunziker]].[http://www.davidemaggio.it/archives/135467/striscia-la-notizia-belen-rodriguez-e-michelle-hunziker-conduttrici] In the autumn of 2016 Belén was the host of the {{ill|third season|it|Tú sí que vales (Italia, terza edizione)}} of the prime time Saturday evening talent show ''{{ill|Tú sí que vales|it|Tú sí que vales}}'' aired by [[Canale 5]]; in this season [[Francesco Sole]] was replaced by [[Simone Rugiati]] as Belén's co-host,{{cite web|url=http://www.davidemaggio.it/archives/134608/simone-rugiati-tu-si-que-vales|title=BOOM! SIMONE RUGIATI A TU SI QUE VALES|publisher=}} and the jury (composed by [[Maria De Filippi]], [[Gerry Scotti]], [[Rudy Zerbi]] and [[Mara Venier]]) was expanded with the addition{{cite web|url=http://www.davidemaggio.it/archives/134859/teo-mammucari-giudice-tu-si-que-vales|title=BOOM! A TU SI QUE VALES ARRIVA IL QUARTO GIUDICE: E' TEO MAMMUCARI|publisher=}} of [[Teo Mammucari]]. In the season 2016-2017 Belén was the [[guest star]] on ''{{ill|L'intervista|it|L'intervista}}'' (aired in October 2016 on [[Canale 5]]){{cite web|url=http://www.gossip.it/news/belen-rodriguez-l-intervista-maurizio-costanzo-stefano-de-martino-news.html|title=Belen Rodriguez, la verità su Stefano De Martino a 'L'Intervista' da Maurizio Costanzo|publisher=}} on ''{{ill|Nemicamatissima|it|Nemicamatissima}}'' (aired in December 2016 by [[Rai 1]]){{cite web|url=http://www.dagospia.com/rubrica-2/media_e_tv/lume-candela-anche-belen-rodriguez-nemica-amatissima-heather-136394.htm|title=a lume di candela – anche belen rodriguez a 'nemica amatissima' con heather parisi e lorella cuccari|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=http://www.tvblog.it/post/1387105/nemicamatissima-anticipazioni-prima-puntata-ospiti|title=Nemicamatissima, anticipazioni prima puntata (Esclusiva Blogo)|publisher=}} on ''{{ill|C'è posta per te|it|C'è posta per te (programma televisivo)}}'' (aired in January 2017 by [[Canale 5]]), on ''{{ill|Emigratis|it|Emigratis}}'' (aired on early April 2017 by [[Italia 1]]) and then on ''{{ill|Maurizio Costanzo Show|it|Maurizio Costanzo Show}}'' (aired on late April 2017 by [[Canale 5]]).[https://www.davidemaggio.it/archives/147164/maurizio-costanzo-show-ospiti-seconda-puntata-simona-ventura] In May–June 2017 Belén took part[https://www.davidemaggio.it/archives/146850/belen-rodriguez-selfie] as "journalist and showgirl" in the second season[http://www.ilgiornale.it/news/spettacoli/selfie-tutto-pronto-seconda-edizione-ventura-e-belen-1392236.html] of the program ''{{ill|Selfie - Le cose cambiano|it|Selfie - Le cose cambiano}}'' aired by [[Canale 5]] and hosted by [[Simona Ventura]]. In the autumn of 2017 Belén was the host of the {{ill|fourth season|it|Tú sí que vales (Italia, quarta edizione)}} of the prime time Saturday evening talent show ''{{ill|Tú sí que vales|it|Tú sí que vales}}'' aired by [[Canale 5]]; in this season Belen's co-host [[Simone Rugiati]] was replaced[https://www.davidemaggio.it/archives/150580/belen-rodriguez-alessio-sakara-e-martin-castrogiovanni-conduttori-di-tu-si-que-vales-2017] by [[Martin Castrogiovanni]] and [[Alessio Sakara]]. In October 2017 Belén was the [[guest star]] in the [[Grande Fratello VIP (season 2)|second season]] of the ''[[Grande Fratello VIP]]'' (aired on [[Canale 5]] and hosted by [[Ilary Blasi]] with [[Alfonso Signorini]])[http://www.tgcom24.mediaset.it/televisione/grande-fratello-vip-belen-rodriguez-entra-in-casa_3099508-201702a.shtml] and in the 5th season of ''{{ill|Chi ha incastrato Peter Pan?|it|Chi ha incastrato Peter Pan?}}'' (aired on [[Canale 5]] and hosted by [[Paolo Bonolis]] with [[Luca Laurenti]]).[http://www.tgcom24.mediaset.it/televisione/-chi-ha-incastrato-peter-pan-belen-e-arisa-ospiti-della-quarta-puntata_3100066-201702a.shtml] Belen was the guest star on ''C'è posta per te'' in March 2018. Belen was the guest star in the [[Amici_di_Maria_De_Filippi#Seventeenth_season_(2017-2018)|17th season]] of the talent show ''[[Amici di Maria De Filippi]]'' with [[Maradona]][https://www.davidemaggio.it/archives/161761/ballando-con-le-stelle-contro-amici-sabato-21-aprile-2018-ascolti][https://www.davidemaggio.it/archives/161768/amici-2018-terza-puntata-serale-heather-parisi-biondo-rudy-zerbi] in April 2018[http://www.tvblog.it/post/1534335/maradona-stasera-ad-amici][http://www.tvblog.it/post/1534153/amici-17-terza-puntata-21-aprile-2018-diretta] and with [[Michelle Hunziker]][https://www.davidemaggio.it/archives/162692/amici-2018-sesta-puntata-cosa-e-successo] in May 2018.[http://www.tvblog.it/post/1540241/amici-17-12-maggio-2018-diretta][http://www.tvblog.it/post/1540476/amici-17-belen-rodriguez-imita-emma-marrone] In the summer of 2018, during the [[2018 FIFA World Cup]], Belén took part (with the [[Gialappa's Band]] and others) in the sports talk show ''{{ill|Balalaika - Dalla Russia col pallone|it|Balalaika - Dalla Russia col pallone}}'' hosted by [[Ilary Blasi]] and [[Nicola Savino]] on [[Canale 5]].[http://www.today.it/media/tv/mondiali-2018-come-vederli-programmi-mediaset.html] In the autumn of 2018 Belén was the host of the {{ill|5th season|it|Tú sí que vales (Italia, quinta edizione)}} of the prime time Saturday evening talent show ''{{ill|Tú sí que vales|it|Tú sí que vales}}'' aired by [[Canale 5]]; in this season [[Mara Venier]] was replaced by [[Iva Zanicchi]] as member of jury.[http://www.tvblog.it/post/1549820/tu-si-que-vales-iva-zanicchi-al-posto-di-mara-venier] == Career and awards == [[File:Belen Rodriguez 1.jpg|thumb|upright|Belén photographed with [[brown hair]]]] === Awards === {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! {{Infobox football club | clubname = Butha-Buthe Warriors | image = | fullname = Butha-Buthe Warriors| ground = Butha-Buthe Field| capacity = 1,000|
manager = [[Thoo Letšaba]]| league = [[Lesotho A-Division]]| }} Butha-Buthe Warriors is a Lesotho football club based in the town of [[Butha-Buthe]].
In 2016/17 Butha-Buthe Warriors played in the [[Lesotho Premier League]], but were relegated with the worst points total in a decade, winning only one game all season. They currently play in Lesotho A-Division North Stream.<ref>https://www.facebook.com/Lesotho-A-Division-League-Southern-And-Northern-Stream-Lesotho-366492773738924/</ref>
==External links== *[https://us.soccerway.com/teams/lesotho/butha-buthe-warriors/37128/] *[http://molaposportscentre.blogspot.com/2017/05/butha-buthe-warriors-vow-to-return-to.html]

[[File:City Chess Elista Kalmykia.jpg|300px|right|thumb|The main building of the Chess City complex]]
'''Chess City''' (also referred to as '''City-Chess'''; {{lang-ru|Сити-Чесс}} ''Siti-Chess'' or {{lang|ru|Город Шахмат}} ''Gorod Shakhmat'', {{lang-xal|Сити-Чесс}}, ''Siti-Çess'') is a large complex devoted to [[chess]] and chess competitions located east of [[Elista]], [[Kalmykia]], in [[Russia]]. The neighborhood-size development consists of a central, four-story domed City Chess Hall surrounded by an [[Olympic Village|Olympic-style village]] of Californian-[[Mediterranean Revival Style architecture]]. The site has a conference center, public swimming pool and a museum of Kalmyk [[Buddhist art]]. The complex features sculptures and artwork devoted to chess, including a statue of [[Ostap Bender]], a fictional character of popular books written by Ilya Ilf and Yevgeni Petrov, who proposed a creation of world chess capital. The complex has been used to host visiting dignitaries like the [[Dalai Lama]].
Completed in 1998, the idea and development of Chess City is directly the result of [[Kirsan Ilyumzhinov]], Kalmykia's millionaire President who has ruled the republic since 1993 and been president of [[FIDE]], the international governing body of chess, since 1995. A fanatical chess enthusiast,<ref name="autogenerated1">[http://www.spiegel.de/international/spiegel/0,1518,442158,00.html The Dictator and His Hobby: Kalmykian Leader Makes Farce of Chess Championships - International - SPIEGEL ONLINE - News<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Ilyumzhinov had the complex built in time for the [[33rd Chess Olympiad]].
Chess City has hosted three major FIDE tournaments: the XXXIII [[Chess Olympiad]] in 1998, the 2004 [[Women's World Chess Championship]], and the [[FIDE World Chess Championship 2006|2006 World Chess Championship]].
Future plans for Chess City include a water sport complex, skiing center, government buildings, business centers, opera and ballet theaters, museums, a conservatory, an art school, religious academies, a center of traditional medicine, and residences for any ambassadors who may be accredited to Kalmykia.
==Controversy==
Kalmykia is a poor republic of approximately 300,000 people located in the barren [[steppe]] regions in the southeastern corner of Europe. Without much in terms of natural resources, the nation is economically depressed and many of its citizens live in poverty.<ref name=NYT062004>Seth Mydans, [https://www.nytimes.com/2004/06/20/international/europe/20russ.html Where Chess Is King and the People Are the Pawns], ''[[The New York Times]]'', June 20, 2004, Accessed May 17, 2006.</ref> As a result, the construction of the opulent Chess City was greatly criticized for spending large sums of money on a tourist resort. Chess tournament winners are sometimes rewarded with a diamond [[tiara]]. Additionally, the desert climate of the area puts many of the planned expansions for Chess City, like the water sports complex, under scrutiny.<ref name="NYT062004"/>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==Further reading== *Seth Mydans, [https://www.nytimes.com/2004/06/20/international/europe/20russ.html Where Chess Is King and the People Are the Pawns], ''[[The New York Times]]'', June 20, 2004, ''Accessed May 17, 2006''. *Julia Emm, [http://www.chessfidelity.com/elections.php?txt_id=91 Chess Paradise], ''Chess Fidelity'', ''Accessed May 17, 2006''.
==External links== *[http://www.kosteniuk.com/albums/elista2004opening/elista2004opening.html Photo Gallery of Chess City] from [[International Grandmaster]] [[Alexandra Kosteniuk]]'s website

{{Infobox stadium | name = Ferney Park | fullname = Ferney Park | location = [[Ballinamallard]], [[Northern Ireland]] | built = 1975 | opened = | renovated = 2006 | expanded = 2012 | owner = [[Ballinamallard United F.C.]] | surface = Grass | capacity = 2,000 (250 seated) | tenants = [[Ballinamallard United F.C.|Ballinamallard United]]
[[Fermanagh Mallards F.C.|Fermanagh Mallards]] | website = }} {{use dmy dates|date=March 2012}} '''Ferney Park''' is a [[football (soccer)|football]] [[stadium]] in [[Ballinamallard]], [[County Fermanagh]], [[Northern Ireland]]. It is the home stadium of [[Ballinamallard United F.C.|Ballinamallard United]]. It was first used by Ballinamallard United in 1975, when the club was founded.{{cite web|url=http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/local-national/northern-ireland/meet-the-mighty-mallards-the-little-ducks-who-ruffled-linfields-feathers-28871872.html |title=Meet the Mighty Mallards... the little ducks who ruffled Linfield's feathers |publisher=Belfast Telegraph |date=2012-10-10 |accessdate=2013-03-17}} == History == Since 2006, Ferney Park has undergone a number of renovations. The ground did not meet the criteria for use in the [[IFA Championship]], which was established in 2008, and Ballinamallard played its home matches at [[Holm Park]], the home of [[Armagh City F.C.|Armagh City]], during the 2008/09 season and the first part of 2009/10, while it was brought up to standard. Ballinamallard's first match back at the upgraded Ferney Park was on 5 December 2009.''Impartial Reporter'', 3 December 2009, [http://www.impartialreporter.com/sport/football/articles/2009/12/03/390350-time-to-stand-and-deliver/ Time to stand and deliver][http://www.ifachampionship.com/report051209_balapor.htm Ballinamallard United 0-5 Portadown] Floodlights were installed in 2010.[http://www.ifachampionship.com/news160310_2.htm Let There Be Light!] In 2012, Ballinamallard United were promoted to the [[IFA Premiership]] after receiving a domestic licence to do so from the [[Irish Football Association]].{{cite web|url=http://www.u.tv/Sport/IFA-makes-new-season-licence-decisions/fc87ce98-7503-48c1-b037-1ab553ec9923 |title=IFA makes new season licence decisions |publisher=UTV |date= |accessdate=2013-03-17}} However at the time, Ferney Park did not meet the required standards. The club were in the process of building two new stands, funded by fans buying seats.{{cite web|url=http://www.impartialreporter.com/news/roundup/articles/2012/06/23/397160-video-ballinamallard-utd-prepare-for-top-flight-football/ |title=VIDEO: Ballinamallard Utd prepare for top flight football |publisher=Impartial Reporter |date=2012-06-23 |accessdate=2013-03-17}} The plans and designs of the new stands were printed on the cover of the matchday programme for United's last game before being promoted against [[Ards F.C.|Ards]].{{cite web|url=http://www.impartialreporter.com/news/roundup/articles/2012/04/28/396518-party-time-at-ferney-park/ |title=Party time at Ferney Park |publisher=Impartial Reporter |date=2012-04-28 |accessdate=2013-03-17}} The building of the stands could not be guaranteed to be completed before the start of the Irish Premiership season. As a result, the club were obliged to nominate [[Stangmore Park]] in [[Dungannon]], [[County Tyrone]] as their home ground if construction could not be finished in time. At a cost of £80,000 from four fans, the pitch at Ferney Park was also re-laid in preparation.{{cite web|last=Edgar |first=Damien |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/19154740 |title=Mallards ready to mix it with elite |publisher=BBC Sport |date=2012-08-09 |accessdate=2013-03-17}} However, the work was finished in time for Ferney Park to be used to host Ballinamallard's opening game against [[Dungannon Swifts F.C.|Dungannon Swifts]].{{cite web|author=GMT |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/19209310 |title=Ballinamallard prepare for Premiership bow against Dungannon |publisher=BBC Sport |date=2012-08-10 |accessdate=2013-03-17}} The new stands were also officially opened for this match.{{cite web|url=http://fermanaghherald.com/2012/08/new-stands-officially-opened-at-ferney-park/ |title=New stands officially opened at Ferney Park |publisher=Fermanagh Herald |date=2012-08-15 |accessdate=2013-03-17}} In December 2012, during half-time in a match between Ballinamallard United and [[Linfield F.C.|Linfield]], the Ferney Park [[pitch invasion|pitch was invaded]] by twenty Linfield supporters who waved [[Union Flag]]s from the centre of the pitch. This was done as part of the [[Belfast City Hall flag protests]]. Ballinamallard United had no prior warning that this would happen and the [[Police Service of Northern Ireland]] took no actions amid fears of inflaming the situation.{{cite web |url=http://www.impartialreporter.com/news/roundup/articles/2012/12/11/399142-mallards-disgusted-after-flag-protest/ |title=Mallards 'disgusted' after flag protest |publisher=Impartial Reporter |date=2012-12-11 |accessdate=2013-03-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121213174640/http://www.impartialreporter.com/news/roundup/articles/2012/12/11/399142-mallards-disgusted-after-flag-protest/ |archivedate=13 December 2012 |df=dmy }} == Usage == Ferney Park is home to Ballinamallard United and is also used to host their reserves' matches.{{cite web|url=http://www.impartialreporter.com/sport/football/articles/2012/12/28/399316-reserves-take-second-half-chances-to-stay-top/ |title=Reserves take second half chances to stay top |publisher=Impartial Reporter |date=2012-12-28 |accessdate=2013-03-17}} It is also home to the [[Fermanagh Mallards F.C.|Fermanagh Mallards]] women's football club. In 2012, Ferney Park was used to host the opening game of the [[Northern Ireland Milk Cup]] between Fermanagh and [[England|English]] side, [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]].{{cite web |url=http://www.nimilkcup.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=136:ferney-park-gives-fermanagh-factor-to-milk-cup |title=Ferney Park Gives Fermanagh Factor to Milk Cup |publisher=Milk Cup |date= |accessdate=2013-03-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140101210153/http://www.nimilkcup.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=136%3Aferney-park-gives-fermanagh-factor-to-milk-cup |archivedate=1 January 2014 |df=dmy }} This was done to commemorate the Milk Cup's 30th anniversary by playing competition matches away from the normal locations along the north coast of Northern Ireland.{{cite web|url=http://www.impartialreporter.com/sport/football/articles/2012/07/19/397413-quinn-hoping-ferney-park-will-provide-home-comfort/ |title=Quinn hoping Ferney Park will provide home comfort |publisher=Impartial Reporter |date=2012-07-19 |accessdate=2013-03-17}} Ferney Park has received a reputation in Northern Irish football as being a difficult ground to find{{cite web|first=Liam |last=Beckett |url=http://www.newsletter.co.uk/news/liam-beckett-enjoys-his-journey-to-ferney-park-ballinamallard-1-4232123 |title=Liam Beckett enjoys his journey to Ferney Park, Ballinamallard |publisher=News Letter |date=2012-11-13 |accessdate=2013-03-17}} with members of the media covering games at the stadium often getting lost on their way to it. This sometimes led to television channels having to use Ballinamallard United's own coverage of matches to be broadcast on television.{{cite web|url=http://www.u.tv/Sport/Ballinamallard-upset-Distillery/2003b334-377e-4120-a974-bfe58baf6527 |title=Ballinamallard upset Distillery |publisher=UTV |date= |accessdate=2013-03-17}} This was often attributed to television companies deeming it too expensive to regularly send cameras to Ballinamallard. This situation has been criticized by Ballinamallard residents who feel that television coverage of Ballinamallard United is not as detailed as other teams because of the location of Ferney Park.{{cite web|url=http://fermanaghherald.com/2013/01/tv-companies-accused-of-lacklustre-ballinamallard-coverage/ |title=TV companies accused of lacklustre Ballinamallard coverage |publisher=Fermanagh Herald |date=2013-01-25 |accessdate=2013-03-17}} ==References== {{reflist}} {{coord|54.41435|N|7.59975|W|type:landmark_region:GB|display=title}} [[Category:Association football venues in Northern Ireland]] [[Category:Sports venues in County Fermanagh]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1975]]

{{about|the hydrojet hoverboard|the gas turbines hoverboard|Flyboard Air}}
[[File:Flyboarding in Warsaw.JPG|thumb|Acrobatics with flyboard]] [[File:Flyboarding, Malmö.webm|thumb|Flyboarding in Malmö, Sweden]]
A '''Flyboard''' is a brand of [[hydroflight]]ing device which supplies propulsion to drive the Flyboard into the air to perform a sport known as hydroflying.<ref name="examples">Examples: [https://powerboardexpert.com/what-is-a-flyboard/ Flyboard Ultimate Supercut] Power Board Expert.</ref>
A Flyboard rider stands on a board connected by a long hose to a watercraft. Water is forced under pressure to a pair of boots with jet nozzles underneath which provide thrust for the rider to fly up to {{Convert|15|m|ft|0|abbr=on}} in the air or to dive headlong through the water down to {{Convert|2.5|m|ft|0|abbr=on}}.<ref name="GM">[http://www.gizmag.com/zapata-flyboard-jet-pack-watersport-boots/20772/ Zapata's outrageous, US$6,600 Flyboard - Aquaman meets Iron Man], gizmag.com. Retrieved: 13 August 2013.</ref>{{Failed verification|date=March 2016}}
== History == The Flyboard was invented in Autumn 2012 by a [[France|French]] water-craft rider, Franky Zapata.<ref name="GM"/><ref name="HIST">[http://www.zapata-racing.com/en/flyboard/historique/ History] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130806054354/http://www.zapata-racing.com/en/flyboard/historique/ |date=August 6, 2013 }}, zapata-racing.com. Retrieved: 13 August 2013.</ref> The design allows the device to climb out of the water and be stable in the air. This was achieved by the underfoot propulsion and hand stabilization.<ref name="HIST"/> The French [[Institut national de la propriété industrielle]] (INPI) granted Zapata a patent for his invention.<ref name="HIST"/> The Flyboard was the subject of a lawsuit from competitor [[Jetlev]] which was dropped without prejudice in March 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.priorsmart.com/li-v-flyboard-l6kw/ |title=Li et. al. v. Flyboard, Inc. et. al.|publisher=PriorSmart |accessdate=12 December 2013}}</ref> The device was presented to the public for the first time at the jet ski World Championship 2012 in China.<ref name="HIST"/> Since its introduction in 2012 the Flyboard has sold around 2500 units.
In the 2015 season of [[America's Got Talent]], a flyboard enthusiast named Damone Rippy performed Flyboarding as his act on the show. :
== Technical information ==
The Flyboard is a bolt-on device that is attached to a [[personal water craft]] (PWC). It is designed so that the PWC follows behind the rider’s trail, allowing the rider multiple degrees of freedom, even allowing the rider to go underwater if they desire. The pilot on the Flyboard is secured in by bindings similar to a [[wakeboard]] and the rider is propelled from water jets below the device. The Flyboard is [[buoyant]] for safety, which also allows the rider to rest in the water between rides.<ref>[http://www.zapata-racing.com/flyboard/technique/ Explications Techniques], zapata-racing.com. Retrieved: 10 December 2013.</ref> The use of a [[personal flotation device]] and helmet is required by rental locations for safety purposes to protect against serious head trauma in the event of the rider impacting the PWC or stationary structures, and to protect the ears from damage and discomfort from impacts with the water.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.californiaflyboard.com/FAQ.aspx#14|title=FAQ|work=California Flyboard}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://h2romagazine.com/flyboard-history|title=Zapata Racing & the Flyboard|work=H2RO Magazine}}</ref>
Device power is controlled by a throttle on the PWC. The equipment may be used in two modes: The primary one requires two people, one to control the PWC throttle which regulates the power and height of the rider. The secondary mode relies on an accessory called an Electronic Management Kit (EMK) which allows the rider to control the PWC throttle.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://h2romagazine.com/professional-flyboarders-h2ro/flyboard-pros-talk-electronic-management-kit|title=Flyboard Pros Talk Electronic Management Kit|work=H2RO Magazine}}</ref>
== Competitions == The first Flyboard World Championships took place in [[Doha]], Qatar in October 2012.<ref>[http://www.dogonews.com/2012/10/29/flyboarding-the-new-extreme-sport Flyboarding - The New Extreme Sport?], dogonews.com. Retrieved: 13 August 2013.</ref>
== Movies == For the first time, a Flyboard stunt was done in a [[Bollywood]] film by [[Hrithik Roshan]] in the film ''[[Bang Bang!]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dnaindia.com/entertainment/report-hrithik-beats-hollywood-heroes-in-doing-daring-stunts-2005005|title=Hrithik beats Hollywood heroes in doing daring stunts|work=dna}}</ref>
== See also== {{Commons category|Flyboards|Flyboard}} * [[JetLev]], the first commercial hydroflight jetpack * [[Lindsay McQueen]], a Flyboard athlete in Spain * [[Flyboard Air]], a freeflight turbojet "hoverboard"
== References == {{Reflist}}

{{Infobox venue | name = Fowler Park and Cunningham Field | nickname = Fowler Park | image = [[File:FowlerParkatUSD.jpg|250px]] | fullname = | former_names = | location = [[San Diego, California|San Diego]], [[California|CA]], United States | coordinates = {{coord|32.776|-117.183|display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = May 2012 | built = | opened = February 15, 2013 | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[University of San Diego]] | operator = University of San Diego | surface = [[Bermuda grass]] ([[Infield#In baseball|infield]]/[[Outfield#In cricket and baseball|Outfield]]), [[Synthetic turf]] (Foul areas from [[third base]] to [[first base]]), Crushed red [[brick]] (Infield dirt) | scoreboard = Electronic | construction_cost = $13 million [[United States dollar|USD]] | suites = | architect = [[Populous (company)|Populous]] | project_manager = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | main_contractors = | capacity = 1,700 (expandable to 3,000) | record_attendance = | dimensions = 312 ft. ([[Left field|LF]]), 370 ft. (LCF), 391 ft. ([[Baseball field#outfield|CF]]), 385 ft. (RCF), 327 ft. ([[Right field|RF]]) | tenants = [[San Diego Toreros baseball]] ([[NCAA]] [[Division I (NCAA)|D1]] [[West Coast Conference|WCC]]) (2013-present) }}
'''Fowler Park and Cunningham Field''' is a [[baseball]] venue located on the campus of the [[University of San Diego]] in [[San Diego, California]], United States. It is home to the [[San Diego Toreros baseball]] team, a member of the [[Division I (NCAA)|Division I]] [[West Coast Conference]]. The [[ballpark|park]] was built in 2012-13 and has a [[seating capacity|capacity]] of 1,700 permanent seats, all of which are chair-backed. Its capacity is able to expand to 3,000 spectators for postseason or special event play.<ref name=fowler>{{cite web|last=Kenney|first=Kirk|title=New Yard Next Year at USD|url=http://www.utsandiego.com/news/2012/jan/28/new-yard-next-year-usd/?page=2#article|work=UTSanDiego.com|publisher=The San Diego Union-Tribune|accessdate=25 July 2012|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/69PbZvWO6?url=http://www.utsandiego.com/news/2012/jan/28/new-yard-next-year-usd/?page%3D2|archivedate=2012-07-25|date=28 January 2012|deadurl=yes|df=}}</ref> The stadium was designed by [[Populous (company)|Populous]].
==History== [[File:FowlerParkUSD.jpg|250px|thumb|left|Fowler Park at Cunningham Field during its inaugural season]] The stadium is named after [[Ron Fowler|Ron and Alexis Fowler]] who provided a substantial portion of the $13 million needed to build the ballpark. The field, like its [[John Cunningham Stadium|predecessor]], is named for former San Diego baseball coach John Cunningham.<ref name=bd>{{cite web|title=First Look at USD's Renovated Fowler Park |url=http://ballparkdigest.com/201201304445/college-baseball/features/first-look-at-usds-renovated-fowler-park |work=BallparkDigest.com |accessdate=3 July 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/68soXgwgR?url=http://ballparkdigest.com/201201304445/college-baseball/features/first-look-at-usds-renovated-fowler-park |archivedate=2012-07-03 |date=30 January 2012 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Cunningham was the Torero head coach for 34 seasons.
Fowler Park opened on February 15, 2013 hosting a 3-game series between University of San Diego and their cross town opponents from San Diego State University.
The field is located at 5998 Alcala Park, San Diego, California, on the site previously occupied by its predecessor [[John Cunningham Stadium]].
==Features== Fowler Park features a grand entry archway detailed in 16th century Spanish Renaissance architecture that connects the ballpark with nearby campus architecture. Seating capacity is expandable from 1,700 to 3,000 during NCAA Regionals and Super Regionals with views to the west of [[Mission Bay (San Diego)|Mission Bay]] and the [[Pacific Ocean]]. The stadium also features a 25'x16' digital ICG scoreboard, clubhouse for players and coaches which includes a spacious locker room, player study lounge, coaches' offices, athletic training room, conference room, soft-toss area and mud room. Luxury suites for fans are also available, as well as a press box area for radio/TV/game operations, public restrooms, concessions and ticket office.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.usdtoreros.com/facilities/cunningham-stadium.html|title=USD - Fowler Park |publisher=University of San Diego Athletics|accessdate=March 2, 2018}}</ref>
==See also== * [[List of NCAA Division I baseball venues]]

[[City Saskatchewan|SCN]] | first_aired = {{Start date|2006|9|4}} | last_aired = {{End date|2007|1|13}} | production_website = http://www.sinkingship.ca/series_idareyou.html }} '''''I Dare You''''' is a Canadian [[Children's television series|children's television program]] hosted by Daniel Cook that aired between September 4, 2006 and January 13, 2007.{{cite news|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/life/article105134.ece|title=Can TV help your kids get fit?|date=June 26, 2007|last=March|first=Catherine Dawson|work=[[The Globe and Mail]]|accessdate=4 February 2010}} Cook dares viewers to participate in three physical exercises. At the end of the program all three movements are combined.{{cite news|url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/thestar/access/1117933161.html?dids=1117933161:1117933161&FMT=ABS|title=Exercise series dares kids to join in|date=September 1, 2006|work=[[The Hamilton Spectator]]|pages=G.13|accessdate=4 February 2010}} The program aims to encourage physical activity, not simply passive viewing. Each episode ends with Cook eating healthy food, such as fruit or milk. The program aired for two seasons.{{cite news|url=http://www.thespec.com/article/451851|title=Top 40 Under 40: Daniel Cook|last=Radley|first=Scott|date=October 17, 2008|work=The Hamilton Spectator|accessdate=4 February 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120402015519/http://www.thespec.com/article/451851|archivedate=April 2, 2012}} ==See also== *''[[This is Daniel Cook]]'' ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://picturebox.ca/index.php/series/i_dare_you Picture Box - I Dare You] * [http://www.sinkingship.ca/series_idareyou.html Sinking Ship Entertainment - ''I Dare You''] [[Category:2006 Canadian television series debuts]] [[Category:2007 Canadian television series endings]] [[Category:Canadian children's television series]] [[Category:TVOntario shows]] [[Category:Exercise television programs]] [[Category:2000s Canadian television series]] {{Canada-tv-prog-stub}}

{{Unreferenced|date=September 2016}} {{Infobox venue | stadium_name = Kiel Auditorium | nickname = | image = Municipal Auditorium, St. Louis, Mo (63228).jpg | location = 1401 Clark Avenue
[[St. Louis|St. Louis, Missouri]] 63103 | coordinates = {{coord|38.627972|-90.201782|type:landmark_region:US-MO|display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = | opened = April 14, 1934 | closed = 1991 | demolished = 1992 | owner = | operator = | construction_cost = $6 million | architect = Louis LaBeaume and Eugene S. Klein | former_names = Municipal Auditorium (1934–1943) | tenants = [[St. Louis Billikens men's basketball|Saint Louis Billikens]] ([[NCAA]]) (1945–1968, 1973–1991)
[[St. Louis Hawks]] ([[National Basketball Association|NBA]]) (1955–1968)
[[St. Louis Streak]] ([[Women's Professional Basketball League|WPBL]]) (1979–1981) | seating_capacity = 9,300 |}} '''Kiel Auditorium''' was an [[Arena|indoor arena]] located in [[St. Louis]], [[Missouri]]. It was the home of the [[Saint Louis University|St. Louis University]] basketball team and hosted the [[National Basketball Association|NBA]]'s [[St. Louis Hawks]], from 1955 to 1968. [[Image:Kiel-mohistsoc.jpg|thumb|left|Municipal Auditorium as it appeared in a 1934 nighttime view]] [[Image:The Rolling Stones 1972 by Dan Volonnino.jpg|thumb|left|The Rolling Stones performing at Kiel Auditorium in 1972]] The arena, completed in 1934, at a cost of $6 million, seated 9,300 and was built by Fruin-Colnon Construction. It was originally named the '''Municipal Auditorium''', but was renamed in honor of former St. Louis Mayor [[Henry Kiel]] in 1943.http://basketball.ballparks.com/ A unique feature of the auditorium was that it was split into two; the front of the building was the [[Peabody Opera House|Kiel Opera House]]. It was possible to use both sides at once as the stages were back to back. President [[Harry Truman]] gave a speech there in which both sides were opened to see his speech. The Kiel Auditorium replaced the [[St. Louis Coliseum]] as the city's main indoor arena. In 1955, the auditorium was also the venue for the second international conference of [[Alcoholics Anonymous]], which established the service conference structure for the movement. Kiel Auditorium played host to a variety of concerts and wrestling events, from the 1950s, until its closure in 1991. In [[Miss Universe 1983|1983]], it was the host of the [[Miss Universe Pageant]]. From the 1950s until the 1970s, the Kiel Auditorium was behind only [[Madison Square Garden]] as North America's most famous wrestling arena, hosting three [[NWA World Heavyweight Championship]] title changes from 1959 until 1986. The most notable wrestling event that took place at the Kiel Auditorium was WCW's premier event, [[Starrcade 1990]]. The building was demolished in 1992, but not before hosting the [[Missouri Valley Conference]] men's basketball tournament the preceding year. After its demolition, its games and concerts temporarily went to the [[St. Louis Arena]]. The [[Enterprise Center]] (originally named "Kiel Center", then "Savvis Center", then "Scottrade Center", before the current [[naming rights]] were purchased) now stands on the site of the former Kiel Auditorium. The Opera House portion of the building, on the northern part of the property, facing Market Street, was not torn down. It remained vacant for a while, but was renovated and reopened under the name [[Peabody Opera House]] in 2011. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{s-start-collapsible|header={{s-sta|et}}}} {{succession box | title = Home of the

revision.text:
{{NHL Labour Relations}} The '''NHL lockout''' may refer to any of the four [[Lockout (industry)|labour actions]] in the history of the [[National Hockey League]]: * The '''[[1992 NHL strike]]''', which postponed 30 games of the [[1991–92 NHL season|1991–92 season]] * The '''[[1994–95 NHL lockout]]''', which cancelled many of the games of the [[1994–95 NHL season|1994–95 season]] and shortened the regular season to 48 games per team with no inter-conference games * The '''[[2004–05 NHL lockout]]''', which cancelled all of the games of the [[2004–05 NHL season|2004–05 season]] * The '''[[2012–13 NHL lockout]]''', which cancelled many of the games of the [[2012–13 NHL season|2012–13 season]] and shortened the regular season to 48 games per team with no inter-conference games
==See also== *[[MLB lockout]] *[[MLS lockout]] *[[NBA lockout]] *[[NFL lockout]]
{{NHL}} {{Sport index}}
[[Category:Sports labor disputes in the United States]] [[Category:National Hockey League labor relations]]

{{more citations needed|date=February 2017}} {{Use British English|date=October 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2014}} {{Infobox stadium | image = Odsal main stand.jpg | image_size = 300px | caption = | fullname = Odsal Stadium | location = Rooley Lane, Odsal, [[Bradford]], West Yorkshire, England | coordinates ={{coord|53|45|54|N|1|45|25|W|display=inline,title}} | built = 1897{{cite web |url=http://www.wafll.com/elland-road/elland-road-stats.html |title=Elland Road – Information |accessdate=3 April 2008 |publisher=wafll.com}} | opened = 1933 | renovated = 1964, 1985, 2001–02. | expanded = | demolished = | owner = [[Bradford City Council]] | operator = [[Rugby Football League]] | surface = Grass | scoreboard = Manual | architect = | former_names = | publictransit = {{rail-interchange|gb|Rail}} [[Low Moor railway station|Low Moor]] | tenants =
'''Rugby League'''
[[Bradford Bulls]] (1934–present),
'''Football'''
[[Bradford City A.F.C|Bradford City]] (1985–1986),
'''Speedway'''
[[Bradford Dukes]] (1945–1960, 1986–1997)
| seating_capacity = 22,739{{citation needed|date=April 2018}} | record_attendance = '''All Time'''
102,569 ([[Warrington Wolves|Warrington]] vs [[Halifax RLFC|Halifax]], 5 May 1954)
'''Super League'''
24,020 ([[Bradford Bulls]] vs [[Leeds Rhinos|Leeds]], 3 September 1999) | dimensions = 67.79m x 111.74m }} '''Odsal Stadium''', is a sports stadium in [[Odsal]], [[Bradford]], West Yorkshire. The stadium is currently home of [[Bradford Bulls]] Rugby League team as well as previously home to the [[motorcycle speedway|speedway]] team [[Bradford Dukes]], as well the football team [[Bradford City]] following the [[Bradford City stadium fire|Valley Parade fire]]. Odsal has also been a venue for baseball, basketball, [[kabbadi]], [[show jumping]], tennis, live music and international Rugby League. It is also the [[List of Rugby League stadiums in England|largest rugby league stadium in England]]. The stadium holds the British attendance records for a Rugby match, 102,569 in 1954 at the rugby league [[Warrington Wolves|Warrington]]-[[Halifax R.L.F.C.|Halifax]] [[Challenge Cup]] Final replay,{{sfn | Delaney | 1991 | p=48 }}{{Cite book|title = There were a lot more than that: Odsal 1954|last = Gate|first = Robert|publisher = R.E. Gate|year = 1994|isbn = 9780951119044|location = |pages = }} and for a domestic, non-final Rugby League match, 69,429 at the third round Challenge Cup tie between Bradford Northern and [[Huddersfield Giants|Huddersfield]] in 1953. The highest recorded attendance of the Super League era being 24,020 against neighbouring rivals [[Leeds Rhinos|Leeds]] on 3 September 1999.{{cite web|url = http://www.loverugbyleague.com/club/bradford-bulls/ground-guide/|title = The Provident Stadium|date = 2016|access-date = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }} While its capacity has reduced significantly, it remains the largest stadium in [[Super League]] {{Cite news|url = |title = "Stobart Super League 2012 club-by-club guide".|last = Laybourn|first = Ian|date = 27 January 2012|newspaper = Daily Telegraph |location=London |access-date = }} The stadium is owned by the Bradford City Council, but due to financial problems the [[Rugby Football League]] purchased the lease on it in 2012. ==History== ===1933-1935: Construction and opening=== Formed in 1907, the Bradford Northern club had played at a number of venues including the [[Greenfield Athletic Ground]] in [[Dudley Hill]] and Bowling Old Lane Cricket Club's ground in [[Birch Lane]].{{sfn|Delaney|1991|pp=44–45}} By the early 1920s, however, Birch Lane's limitations were clear and Northern began to seek another home. Precarious finances prevented the club being able to take up an offer to develop land off Rooley Lane or to upgrade and move back to Greenfield, but in 1933, [[Bradford City Council]] gave them the opportunity to transform land at [[Odsal]] Top into their [[home ground]]. On 20 June 1933 the club therefore signed a ten-year deal on the site, which was to become the biggest stadium in England outside [[Wembley Stadium (1923)|Wembley]].{{sfn|Delaney|1991|p=45}} The site was a former quarry which was then being used as a landfill tip. Ernest Call M.B.E., the Director of Cleansing for [[Bradford City Council]] devised a system of controlled tipping that saw 140,000 cart loads of household waste deposited to form the characteristic banking at Odsal. The club were to be responsible for boundary fencing, dressing rooms and seated accommodation. To be able to turf the [[Rugby league playing field|pitch]], and other areas, a turf fund was put into place which raised a total of £900 to cover the work. A stand was erected at the cost of £2,000, which was paid for by the [[Rugby Football League]]. It held 1,500 on a mixture of benches and [[tip-up seat]]s. The ground was officially opened by Sir Joseph Taylor, President of Huddersfield on 1 September 1934. His club went on to beat the hosts 31–16, [[Rugby league in Australia|Australian]] [[winger (sports)|winger]] Ray Markham scoring four [[try|tries]] in front of an estimated 20,000.{{sfn|Delaney|1991|p=45-46}} The clubhouse and dressing rooms were officially opened before a match against [[Hull F.C.]] on 2 February 1935. Contemporary pictures show that as late as August 1935 the banking on the Rooley Avenue side was still being created.{{sfn|Delaney|1991|p=45}} ===1940-1979: Speedway and Rugby League internationals=== In 1945, speedway began in Bradford with the [[Odsal Boomerangs]]. In the post-[[Second World War]] years, speedway proved extremely popular with crowds of over 20,000 regularly attending meetings at Odsal, with the 1946 average for the first year of the [[National League (1932–64)|National League]] after the war. The highest speedway attendance during this period came on 5 July 1947 when 47,050 fans saw [[England national speedway team|England]] defeat [[Australia national speedway team|Australia]] 65-43 in a Test match. This remains the largest-ever speedway crowd for Odsal Stadium. During the [[Second World War]], the lower floor of the clubhouse was also used as an [[Air Raid Precautions]] centre, and one of the dressing rooms was the map room.{{sfn | Delaney | 1991 | pp=46 }} On 20 December 1947, the largest ever attendance for an international test at Odsal was set when 42,685 saw [[England national rugby league team|England]] defeat [[New Zealand Kiwis|New Zealand]] 25–9. The first [[Floodlights (sport)|floodlit]] rugby match in the [[Northern England|North of England]] was held at Odsal in 1951.{{Citation needed|date=April 2013}} In September 1951, Council Engineer Ernest Wardley drew up a plan for a 92,000 capacity 'European' style stadium, at a cost of £250,000.{{cite web |url=http://www.bantamspast.co.uk/grounds/odsal.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110217141638/http://www.bantamspast.co.uk/grounds/odsal.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=17 February 2011 |title=Odsal |date= |website=bantamspast |publisher=The Bradford City Football Club Museum |accessdate=9 May 2014 }} Eventually £50,000 was spent on terracing the Rooley Avenue end in 1964, before the Wardley plan was officially dropped the following year. After a disastrous 1960 season, the Panthers (previously the Odsal Boomerangs) left Odsal and in 1961 moved across town to the [[Greenfield Stadium, Bradford|Greenfield Stadium]], better known for [[greyhound racing]]. After the Panthers folded in 1962, Motorcycle Speedway would not return to Bradford for another 10 years. Speedway returned to Odsal when promoters Les Whaley, Mike Parker and Bill Bridgett moved the [[British League Division Two]] side [[Nelson Admirals]] across the [[Pennines]] for the final eleven league meetings of the 1970 season and went on to adopt Bradford Northern as their name and red, black and amber as their colours. Northern would finish second in Division 2 in 1971, but from there results and attendances steadily declined and the team folded after 1973. The second test of the [[The Ashes (rugby league)|1978 Ashes series]] was played at Odsal, with [[Great Britain Lions|Great Britain]] defeating [[Australian Kangaroos|Australia]] before a crowd of 26,761. The Lions team that day featured what was called a "Dad's Army" front row with [[Jim Mills (rugby league)|Jim Mills]], [[Tony Fisher (rugby)|Tony Fisher]] and [[Brian Lockwood]] all being over the age of 30. ===1980-1990s: Bradford City and the return of Speedway=== The ground's clubhouse had to be refurbished when it was condemned in the mid-1980s. The social facilities were also upgraded at the same time. Speedway returned to Odsal in 1985 after a ten-year absence when it was selected by the [[Fédération Internationale de Motocyclisme|FIM]] to host the [[1985 Individual Speedway World Championship|1985 World Final]]. Following the [[Bradford City stadium fire|Valley Parade fire]] disaster of 1985, [[Bradford City]] played a handful of games at [[Leeds Road]] and [[Elland Road]] whilst the future of Valley Parade was decided.{{Nonspecific|date=April 2013}} On 23 September 1985, a [[Football League]] delegation visited Odsal to view the stadium to pass it fit to host City's home games. Segregation fences were erected on the old Main Stand side and 1,000 uncovered seats were bolted onto the terracing – it was planned to install 7,000 in the future. Meanwhile, a further £1 million was spent to conform with new safety standards – bringing the total spent on Odsal to £3.5 million. New boundary walls, turnstiles, exit gates, a bus layby in Rooley Avenue and access road were added. Odsal played host to [[Bradford City A.F.C.|Bradford City's]] [[Football League Championship|Division Two]] home games until December 1986. Odsal Stadium also held a modern-day attendance record for almost six years.{{clarify|date=February 2012}} Like most British stadia, Odsal had its capacity substantially reduced by the safety measures introduced in the 1990s following the [[Hillsborough disaster]] and the findings of the [[Taylor Report]]. ===2000-present: Redevelopments=== At the dawn of the [[Super League]] era in 1996, Bradford Bulls wanted to attract new sponsors but had poor and outdated hospitality suites. In 2000 they announced plans to build hospitality suites at the South End of the stadium which would mean building on the track around the pitch, effectively ending Speedways association with Bradford. Construction started in 2001 and was completed in 2002 with Bradford Bulls playing two seasons at [[Valley Parade]]. After London won the right to host the [[2012 Olympic Games]] in 2008, plans were put in place for an Olympic Legacy Park at Odsal, which would mean redeveloping the stadium and the Richard Dunn Leisure Centre opposite. Although these plans never came to fruition and a Legacy Park was built in Sheffield instead. In 2012, the Bulls got into financial difficulties and the RFL stepped in and bought the lease to Odsal. In early 2017 the Bulls were liquidated and a new club was formed by Andrew Chalmers who wants to redevelop Odsal into a venue fit for Super League and international rugby league. In 2018 it was revealed [[Bradford Park Avenue]] were in discussions about moving to Odsal. ==Usage== ===Speedway=== The rugby pitch at Odsal Stadium is surrounded by a {{convert|390|yd|m}} [[Dirt track racing|speedway]] track which was used mostly for [[Motorcycle speedway]], though the stadium also hosted stock car racing. After finishing at the bottom of the National League in 1948 and 1949, the Boomerangs folded and were replaced in 1950 by the [[Bradford Tudors|Odsal Tudors]]. Despite the name change, fortunes remained the same with the Tudors finishing on the bottom of the NL ladder in 1951. In 1959 the Tudors dropped the Odsal name and were renamed the Bradford Tudors. The most famous of the Tudors riders was English star [[Nigel Boocock]] who rode for the team from 1955-1957. In 1960, the Bradford Tudors renamed themselves the Bradford Panthers. After a disastrous 1960 season, the Panthers left Odsal and in 1961 moved across town to the [[Greenfield Stadium, Bradford|Greenfield Stadium]], better known for [[greyhound racing]]. After the Panthers folded in 1962, Motorcycle Speedway would not return to Bradford for another 10 years. The sound of speedway bikes was heard once again at Odsal when promoters Les Whaley, Mike Parker and Bill Bridgett moved the [[British League Division Two]] side [[Nelson Admirals]] across the [[Pennines]] for the final eleven league meetings of the 1970 season. The Admirals became Bradford Northern like their rugby league landlords and even adopted their red, black and amber colours, though the move was met with opposition from the nearby [[Halifax Dukes]]. Northern would finish second in Div.II in 1971, but from there results and attendances steadily declined and again, a Bradford speedway team folded after 1973. Speedway wasn't lost to Bradford, or Odsal though as from the [[Bradford Barons]] were formed, but they were also short lived and only lasted the years 1974 and 1975. Speedway would once again not return to Bradford for another 10 years. Speedway returned to Odsal in 1985 after a ten-year absence when it was selected by the [[Fédération Internationale de Motocyclisme|FIM]] to host the [[1985 Individual Speedway World Championship|1985 World Final]], the first time the Final in England would not be held at [[Wembley Stadium (1923)|Wembley Stadium]]. In the three years after the [[1981 Individual Speedway World Championship|1981 World Final]] at Wembley, international speedway's home in Great Britain had been the [[White City Stadium]] in London. However, with the closure of White City in 1985 a new home would be needed and the 30,000 capacity Odsal was chosen. A capacity crowd at the 1985 World Final saw a titanic fight between [[Denmark]]'s defending [[Speedway World Championship|World Champion]] [[Erik Gundersen]], his fellow countryman [[Hans Nielsen (speedway rider)|Hans Nielsen]], and American rider [[Sam Ermolenko]]. The trio all finished the meeting on 13 points each which saw a three-way runoff for the top 3 placings with Gundersen winning from Nielsen and Ermolenko. Just a month prior to the World Final, Odsal also hosted the Overseas Final as part of the World Final qualifications. That meeting saw two riders finish at the top on 14 points, American [[Shawn Moran]] and English favourite, Halifax Dukes rider [[Kenny Carter]]. Moran would defeat Carter in the runoff for the Overseas title. In March 1986, Odsal opened its doors to [[British League]] action for the first time since the 1950s after the Halifax Dukes were offered a new home track. The new 'Bradford Dukes' team would in later years include World Champions [[Gary Havelock]] and [[Mark Loram]], multiple British and [[Individual Speedway Long Track World Championship|Long Track World Champions]] [[Simon Wigg]] and [[Kelvin Tatum]], and dual [[Australian Individual Speedway Championship|Australian Champion]] [[Glenn Doyle]]. However, the club suffered the tragic loss of Kenny Carter who died in murder/suicide after shooting his wife and then himself at their home in May 1986. Odsal Stadium hosted its second World Final in [[1990 Individual Speedway World Championship|1990]]. [[Swedish people|Swedish]] rider [[Per Jonsson]] won his only World Championship when he defeated Shawn Moran in a runoff after both had finished the meeting on 13 points. Moran was later stripped of his silver medal by the FIM after he had tested positive to a drug test taken three months earlier at the Overseas Final in [[Coventry]]. Moran claimed that the drug he took was a pain killer prescribed by a doctor in Sweden, but the FIM stood firm. They also did not upgrade the standings and the official records show no second place rider. Young Australian rider [[Todd Wiltshire]] riding in his first World Final surprised many by finishing in third place with 12 points. From 1987, Bradford speedway then enjoyed its greatest period of success, winning eight trophies until the club's closure in 1997 when despite winning the [[Elite League (speedway)|Elite League]], the club folded for the third time. Odsal Stadium hosted the [[1997 Speedway Grand Prix of Great Britain|1997]] [[Speedway Grand Prix of Great Britain]]. Danish rider [[Brian Andersen]] won the Grand Prix from America's [[1996 Speedway Grand Prix|reigning World Champion]] [[Billy Hamill]], with Swede [[Jimmy Nilsen]] finishing third in the Final. Bradford Dukes rider Mark Loram finished 4th in the Final. Loram would later go on to be the [[2000 Speedway Grand Prix|2000 World Champion]] after winning the [[Speedway Grand Prix]] series that year. ====Speedway World Finals==== =====Individual World Championship===== * [[1985 Individual Speedway World Championship|1985]] - {{flagicon|DEN}} [[Erik Gundersen]] 13+3pts * [[1990 Individual Speedway World Championship|1990]] - {{flagicon|SWE}} [[Per Jonsson]] 13+3pts =====World Pairs Championship===== * [[1988 Speedway World Pairs Championship|1988]] - {{flagicon|DEN}} [[Denmark national speedway team|Denmark]] ([[Hans Nielsen (speedway rider)|Hans Nielsen]] / [[Erik Gundersen]]) 45pts =====World Team Cup===== * [[1986 Speedway World Team Cup|1986]]* - {{flagicon|DEN}} [[Denmark national speedway team|Denmark]] ([[Erik Gundersen]] / [[Hans Nielsen (speedway rider)|Hans Nielsen]] / [[Tommy Knudsen]] / [[Jan O. Pedersen]] / [[John Jørgensen]]) - 130pts * [[1989 Speedway World Team Cup|1989]] - {{flagicon|ENG}} [[England national speedway team|England]] ([[Jeremy Doncaster]] / [[Kelvin Tatum]] / [[Paul Thorp]] / [[Simon Wigg]] / [[Simon Cross]]) - 48pts ''* Odsal hosted the third of 3 rounds in the Final.'' ====Speedway Grand Prix==== * [[1997 Speedway Grand Prix of Great Britain]] - {{flagicon|DEN}} [[Brian Andersen]] ==Layout== ===Rooley Avenue End=== [[File:Odsal Rooley Avenue End.jpg|200px|right]] '''Capacity- 7,290 (standing)'''
The Rooley Avenue End is situated at the Northern end of the stadium. It is open terracing and is where the big screen is erected for televised games. The stand has turnstiles that back onto Rooley Avenue. ===East Stand=== [[File:Odsal main stand.jpg|200px|right]] '''Capacity- 4,890 (seating)'''
The East Stand is the only part of the ground that is covered and has seating. The stand runs parallel to the pith and has ''BULLS'' spelt out on the seats. The stand houses hone supporters and most season ticket holders as well as the press and some executive seats. There is also bars and toilets at the top of the stand. ===South Bank=== [[File:South Bank.jpg|200px|right]] '''Capacity- 620 (seating)'''
The South Bank is the stadiums hospitality stand which sits at the Southern end of the ground. It has two levels each containing a banquiting suite and seats looking out onto the pitch. Speedway ended its association with Odsal after the hospitality building was built on turns 3 and 4. ===West Stand=== [[File:West Stand at Odsal.jpg|200px|right]] '''Capacity- 9,309 (standing)'''
The West Stand is uncovered terracing and houses the players changing rooms and tunnel as well as TV gantry at the top of the stand. The supporters bar is located in the north-west corner of the stand and also houses a manual scoreboard and clock. At the top of the stand, on ground level with Rooley Avenue is the car park and club shop and ticket office. There are a few hospitality boxes at the top of the stand bit these are not used after the construction of the South Bank. ===The pitch=== The pitch at Odsal has a distinctive concave contour, with the corners of the pitch behind the try-line noticeably sloping up towards the stands. This was due to the stadium being used to host [[Motorcycle speedway|speedway]] events and so the corners of the pitch were removable to allow full use of the track. With the end of speedway at Odsal, the upturned corners are no longer as pronounced as they once were. ===Future=== As there has been little investment in the stadium, apart from the South Bank being built in 2002, most of the stadium is run down. In the run up to the 2012 London Olympics, Bradford City Council applied for an Olympic Legacy Park to be built at Odsal and the site of Richards Dunn Sport Centre. Bradford's bid was turned down in favour of Sheffield, which means it is highly unlikely and improvements will be made to Odsal in the near future. However when Andrew Chalmers bought the club in 2017, he expressed an interest in redeveloping the stadium for it to be fit for Super League and future international test matches. ==Sponsorship== {| class="wikitable" |- bgcolor=#bdb76b ! Year!! Sponsor !! {{Infobox venue | stadium_name = Rungrado 1st of May Stadium | fullname = | image = Views from Yanggakdo International Hotel 10.JPG | location = [[Rŭngrado|Rungra Island]], {{nowrap|[[Pyongyang]], [[North Korea]]}} | coordinates = {{Coord|39|2|58|N|125|46|31|E|region:KP_type:landmark_scale:3700|display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = | built = | opened = {{Start date|1989|05|01|df=y}} | closed = | demolished = | owner = | surface = Artificial turf{{cite web|title=North Korea: Rungrado May Day to undergo thorough revamp|url=http://stadiumdb.com/news/2013/09/north_korea_rungrado_may_day_to_undergo_thorough_revamp|website=Stadium DB|accessdate=21 July 2017}} | architect = | dimensions = Main pitch – 22,500 m²
Total floor space – over 207,000 m² | tenants = [[North Korea national football team]]
[[North Korea women's national football team]]
[[April 25 Sports Club]] | image_size = 250 | alt = | construction_cost = | former_names = | seating_capacity = ~114,000{{cite web|url=http://stadiumdb.com/news/2016/08/north_korea_kims_shrinking_pride|title=North Korea: Kim’s shrinking pride – StadiumDB.com|website=stadiumdb.com}}| }} {{Infobox Korean name |context=north |img= |caption= |hangul={{linktext|릉|라|도}} 5{{linktext|월}}1{{linktext|일| 경기장}} |hanja={{linktext|綾|羅|島| 五|月|一|日| 競技場}} |rr=Neungnado 5(o)-wol 1(ir)-il Gyeonggijang |mr=Rŭngrado Owŏl Iril Kyŏnggijang }} [[File:Arirang Mass Games 01.JPG|thumb|Exterior of Rungrado May Day Stadium]] [[File:Arirang Mass Games 12.JPG|thumb|[[Arirang Festival]], on the occasion of the 100th Anniversary of the birth of [[Kim Il-sung]].]] The '''Rungrado 1st of May Stadium''', also known as the '''May Day Stadium''', is a [[multi-purpose stadium]] in [[Rŭngrado|Rungra Island]], [[Pyongyang]], [[North Korea]] which was opened on 1 May 1989. Its first major event was the [[13th World Festival of Youth and Students]]. It is the [[list of stadiums by capacity|largest stadium in the world]], with a total capacity of approximately 114,000. The site occupies an area of {{Convert|20.7|ha|acre}}. It is commonly confused with the nearby 50,000 capacity [[Kim Il-sung Stadium]] due to proximity, but possesses unique size and seating capacities which provide distinction. ==Name== Its name comes from [[Rŭngrado|Rungra Island]] in the [[Taedong River]], upon which it is situated, and from the [[International Workers' Day]] celebrated on [[May Day]] every year. ==Uses== It is currently used for [[football (soccer)|football]] matches, a few [[athletics (track and field)|athletics]] events, but most often for the [[mass games]] of the [[Arirang Festival]]. Officially, the stadium can seat 150,000 people, but the real capacity is under 114,000. Even the lower actual capacity ranks first on the [[List of stadiums by capacity|list of largest stadiums by capacity in the world]].{{cite web|url=http://www.football-lineups.com/stadium/460/|title=Rungrado 1st of May Stadium – Football Stadium|work=Football-Lineups|accessdate=26 May 2016}} ==Design== Its scalloped roof features 16 [[arch]]es arranged in a ring, and resembles a [[magnolia]] blossom. It hosts events on a main pitch sprawling across over 22,500 m² (242,200 ft²). Its total floor space is over 207,000 m² (2.2 million ft²) across eight stories, and the lobes of its roof peak at more than 60 m (197 ft) from the ground. ==History== After the [[1988 Summer Olympics]] had been awarded to [[Seoul]], North Korea doubled down its efforts to present itself as the legitimate Korean state. As part of these efforts, it successfully bid to organize the [[13th World Festival of Youth and Students]] in Pyongyang in 1989. Massive construction projects were initiated in preparation for the festival, one of which was the Rungrado 1st of May Stadium. At the time of completion, it was the largest stadium ever built in Asia.{{cite book|last=Cha|first=Victor|title=The Impossible State: North Korea, Past and Future|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=AShswwfIbqsC&pg=PA120|year=2012|publisher=Random House|location=London|isbn=978-1-4481-3958-3|page=120}} While the stadium is used for sporting events, it is most famous as the site of massive performances and shows celebrating [[Kim Il-sung]] and the North Korean nation. In June–July 2002 it was the site of a large choreographed "[[Arirang Festival]]" gymnastic and artistic performance. The extravaganza involved for the first time some 100,000+ participants—double the number of spectators,{{cite news|last=Watts|first=Jonathan|url=https://www.theguardian.com/korea/article/0,2763,717149,00.html|title=Despair, hunger and defiance at the heart of the greatest show on earth|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=17 May 2002 | location=London}} and was open to foreigners. These performances are now an annual feature in Pyongyang, usually in August and September. The event in 2007 was recognized by the [[Guinness Book of Records]] as the largest gymnastic display with 100,090 participants.http://www.guinnessworldrecords.com/world-records/largest-gymnastic-display In the late 1990s, a number of North Korean army generals implicated in an assassination attempt on [[Kim Jong-il]] were [[death by burning|executed via burning]] in the stadium.{{cite news |title=Train blast was 'a plot to kill North Korea's leader' |first=Sergey |last=Soukhorukov |work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/northkorea/1464413/Train-blast-was-a-plot-to-kill-North-Koreas-leader.html |date=13 June 2004}} In 2000 Kim Jong-il entertained [[Madeleine Albright]], the [[United States Secretary of State]] under President [[Bill Clinton]].{{cite web|title=Is Kim her next challenge?|url=http://www.atimes.com/atimes/Korea/ML06Dg01.html|work=Asia Times Online|accessdate=31 December 2011}} ''[[Collision in Korea]]'' was the largest [[professional wrestling]] pay-per-view event ever that was jointly produced by [[World Championship Wrestling]] and [[New Japan Pro-Wrestling]]. It took place over a period of two days on April 28 and 29, 1995 at the stadium and had an attendance of 150,000 and 190,000 according to local authorities. It did not air in North America until August 4, 1995. American wrestling journalist Dave Meltzer has claimed that the actual combined attendance for the two-day-event was somewhere around 160,000 total.{{cite web|url=http://whatculture.com/wwe/16-ppvs-not-on-the-wwe-network?page=5 |title=16 PPVs NOT On The WWE Network – Page 5 |publisher=Whatculture.com |date=2014-07-17 |accessdate=2016-05-26}} After a two-year renovation project, the stadium reopened in 2015. In July 2017, the Rungnado Stadium played host to six group stage matches as part of [[2018 AFC U-23 Championship qualification]].{{cite web|title=Schedule & Results|url=http://www.the-afc.com/afcasfeeds?view=all&id=202&type=Stage#ui-tabs-1|website=Asian Football Confederation|accessdate=23 July 2017}} In the [[September 2018 inter-Korean summit]] in Pyeongyang, President [[Moon Jae-in]] of South Korea gave a speech with Chairman [[Kim Jong-un]] to 150,000 North Korean spectators. The speech has themes of unification, peace, and cooperation. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hJod7qg2GCc ==Notable events== *Opening and closing ceremonies of the [[13th World Festival of Youth and Students]] in 1989 *[[Collision in Korea]] professional wrestling event in 1995 *[[September 2018 inter-Korean summit|2018 Inter-Korean Summit Pyeongyang]] ===Annual Events=== *[[Arirang Festival]] *[[Pyongyang Marathon]] == See also == {{Portal|North Korea|Sport}} * [[List of football stadiums in North Korea]] * [[Strahov Stadium]] * [[Yanggakdo Stadium]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Rŭngrado May First Stadium|Rŭngnado Stadium}} * [http://www.dprk360.com/360/rungrado_may_day_stadium/ Rungnado May Day Stadium 360 degree panorama] * [https://maps.google.com/maps?q=Pyongyang,+North+Korea&hl=en&ie=UTF8&ll=39.049535,125.775089&spn=0.005141,0.00912&sll=37.0625,-95.677068&sspn=42.766543,74.707031&oq=pyongyang&hnear=P'y%C5%8Fngyang,+Pyongyang,+North+Korea&t=h&z=17 Rungnado May Day Stadium view from above] {{Stadiums in North Korea}} [[Category:1989 establishments in North Korea]] [[Category:Athletics (track and field) venues in North Korea]] [[Category:Event venues established in 1989]] [[Category:Football venues in North Korea]] [[Category:Multi-purpose stadiums in North Korea]] [[Category:National stadiums|North Korea]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1989]] [[Category:Sports venues in Pyongyang]]

{{refimprove|date=March 2013}} {{Infobox venue | stadium_name = Terry Park Ballfield | nickname = | image = [[File:Fort Myers Terry Park Ballfield02.jpg|250px]] | location = 3410 [[State Road 80 (Florida)|Palm Beach Boulevard]] [[Fort Myers, Florida]], United States | coordinates = {{coord|26.65709|-81.84199}} | broke_ground = [[1921 in baseball|1921]] | opened = [[1925 in baseball|1925]] | renovated = [[1955 in baseball|1955]] (Rebuilt) | expanded = | closed = | demolished = [[1943 in baseball|1943]] by Fire

(2010 Renovation Cost) | architect = | project_manager = | main_contractors = Chris-Tel Construction
